Award.AbstractNarration:
Face-to-face conversation plays a key role in children's language acquisition and adult communication, and in the evolution of languages over time. However, surprisingly little is known about the cognitive mechanisms that affect language use in conversation. One feature of conversation is that what we say and how we say it depends on our insights into the knowledge and beliefs of the people we talk to. Sometimes these insights are correct, sometimes they fail dramatically, and other times the insights are still unformed. This research project will explore how insights into others are formed, how these insights are used, and how they may fail. A series of experiments will use eye-tracking technology to study these processes on a moment-by-moment basis as they occur in natural conversation. The work draws from recent advances in psycholinguistics, developmental psychology, and social psychology.

This project will provide insights into a poorly understood but core component of language, that is, appreciating the perspectives of others. It has potentially diverse implications, including improving education through perspective-taking in teacher-student dyads and in math education through the use of perspective-taking in reasoning about the geometry of multi-dimensional figures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Face-to-face conversation is often considered the most basic form of language use, however, surprisingly little is known about the mechanisms by which we use language in conversation. With support from the NSF, the investigator explored the mechanisms driving language use in interactive conversation. This project used experimental studies of language use and processing to test theories about a poorly understood, but core component of language—appreciating the perspectives of others. This research involved approximately 75 undergraduate research assistants, 6 graduate students and 4 elderly volunteers, each of whom gained hands-on training in experimental methods and theory. Computer code developed for this project is shared freely on the web, and is used nationwide by researchers at peer institutions. In many cases, raw data from these studies is publically available to support future scientific inquiry. This work is summarized in 9 academic publications and 13 scientific conference presentations to date. Discussions of this research designed to be accessible to the general public are made available on the web. A focus of this work was to understand the way in which people do (or don’t) take the perspective of others when speaking in group settings.

One series of experiments demonstrated that speakers are sensitive to how much others in a group do and don’t know about the topic at hand, and adjust the way in which they speak accordingly. Parallel examinations of understanding in group settings showed that listeners may “tune out” when they are not being directly addressed.   Studies of memory for conversation show that people tend to remember best what they themselves have said in a conversation. These findings suggest that problems in communication may arise when speakers and listeners, due to simple memory phenomena, have different memories of what they have talked about.   Studies of the moment-by-moment processes by which listeners take into account the perspective of the speaker when understanding language show very rapid use of perspective in multiple domains including spatial reasoning and knowledge about past topics of conversation. For example, when a speaker asks a question, listeners rapidly – in less than a second – understand the speaker to be asking about something that the speaker does not know but that the listener does know. This rapid interpretation process is guided not only by the words in the question, but in addition by the intonation of that question—whether it rises or falls at the end. Studies of individual differences in perspective taking provide initial evidence that skilled perspective-taking when speaking does not necessarily translate into skilled perspective-taking when listening. Instead these may be independent processes.

A potential broad implication of this work comes from the finding that not everyone walks away from a conversation with the same understanding of what was said or what was agreed upon. This could have potentially broad implications in a variety of domains, including, for example, conflict resolution: If you have a negotiation with a group of people, it may be important to be aware of the fact that not all of those individuals will encode the same information about what was discussed. Instead, it is the person who introduced the resolution in the first place that is likely to best remember the details of what was agreed upon. This suggests that taking turns talking, or having each person re-formulate the agreement in their own words, or perhaps committing everything to writing may be an important safe-guard to make sure everyone understands what is being discussed and agreed upon. One way in which this research might be applied more generally is in the domain of human-computer interaction. Human-computer interactions (such as interactions with the Siri system on the iPhone), might be more successful if the computer adapted to the user’s background knowledge, providing information at the right level for the user’s knowledge base and experience. Similar adaptations could prove useful in improving communication between computer systems and groups of people, as in situations where you hear information about an exhibit at a museum, or when making announcements at the train station. Such technology could be employed to help all listeners, when alone or in groups, to better understand the information.
